Introduction This addendum expands on the 2018 report “Water Resource Assessment in the New Mexico Permian Basin” (SAND2018-12018) (Lowry et al., 2018), in which the groundwater in the New Mexico area of the Permian Basin was evaluated to examine potential quantity and quality impacts due to regional development activities and provide baseline data from which future changes can be measured and establish a long-term monitoring network within the Basin. According to the New Mexico Oil Conservation Division there are 48,745 wells producing oil or gas in New Mexico as of August 8, 2020. Furthermore, future investment in infrastructure predicted through 2030 could boost New Mexico’s oil production by 358%, natural gas by 106%, and natural gas liquids by 136% (IER, 2020). As the number of wells increase, the demand for water and infrastructure will increase accordingly. This study aims to address the region’s ability to respond to industry demands, while protecting human health and the environment. In this addendum, the water level and quality of select wells located on BLM managed land in three high potential areas (HPAs), which are associated with the Alto Platform, Bone Spring, and Delaware Mountain Group plays, were assessed (Lowry et al., 2018). These HPAs were derived from the Reasonable Foreseeable Development Scenario in which oil and gas plays in Chavez, Lea, Eddy, and Roosevelt counties were ranked on their potential for future development. “High” and “Very High” potential areas have the potential to support 50 to 100 and >100 new wells per year, respectively (Engler et al., 2012). A combination of field measurements and laboratory analyses were assessed to establish current conditions and to determine if significant changes have occurred since the previous report. Field measurements include manual and continuous depth-to-water measurements and flowmeter readings in wells equipped with pumps. Water quality samples were also collected from wells, where possible, and samples were sent to Hall Environmental Analysis Laboratories (HEAL) for analysis of total dissolved solids (TDS) and total anion/cation balance, with some wells also tested for total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH). The data are presented herein and compared to 2018 data, where applicable, with any trends and outliers being noted. 2. Water Quality Basic water quality parameters were analyzed on samples collected from thirteen wells and the results were compared to the 2018 results. The water quality analyses and their associated results are discussed further in the following subsections. 2.1 Sampling Method and Analyses Performed Wells targeted for sampling were selected based on their location and accessibility. Samples were collected from wells via outlets from existing pumping equipment or with a downhole bailer. Examples of pre-existing equipment include wind-powered pumps (Windmills), such as at S-2016-063 and S-2016-097 wells, or hose spigots. To collect a representative sample, water was allowed to flow from the spigots for about five minutes prior to sample collection. Ten of the wells sampled were collected using the bailer method and three were collected utilizing existing well equipment. The following parameters were analyzed by HEAL: pH Specific Conductance (Sp. Cond.) HEAL is located in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and holds certifications for drinking water chemical and drinking water microbiological analysis from the State of New Mexico Environment Department. 12 2.2 General Water Quality in the Area Wells sampled in this study are either completed or open to the Rustler Formation, which includes the Culebra and Magenta Aquifers, and/or the Dockum Formation, which includes the Dewey Lake and Santa Rosa Aquifers. The 2018 study included assessments of wells completed in the Pecos and Capitan Reef Aquifers; however, the Water Quality section of this addendum does not include any of those wells. Waters completed in these aquifers are often high in salinity – primarily sourced from salts such as sodium chloride and calcium sulfate – with higher salinity reaching concentrations of 35,000 milligrams per liter to the east of the Pecos River and fresher water to the west (Houston et. al. 2015; NMOSE, 2016). Shallow groundwater quality can be very good (i.e., fresher) but degrades as the presence of salt, gypsum, and other evaporite deposits increase at lower depths (NMOSE, 2016). Total dissolved solids concentration is a primary indicator of the regions water quality; water with high TDS is less suitable for drinking or irrigation. Summary and Recommendation Water chemistry and level data were compared to baseline data established in the 2018 SAND2018-12018 report. Water quality samples were collected using bailers or existing pumps and analyzed by Hall Environmental Analysis Laboratory. Thirteen wells completed in or open to the Rustler Formation, which includes the Culebra and Magenta Aquifers, and/or the Dockum Formation, which includes the Dewey Lake and Santa Rosa Aquifers, were sampled for pH, TDS, and cation/anion balance, with nine wells also tested for TPH. Laboratory results were then compared to applicable NMWQCC standards. 56 According to 2019 water quality results, all wells in the Center North and South HPAs recorded exceedances in TDS and SO42- and all wells in the Center North and five wells in the South HPA reported exceedances in Cl-. One well in both the Center North and South HPAs reported exceedances of F- and NO2 + NO3. No wells in the North HPA reported exceedances in standards. Results from the 2020 water quality sampling indicated all wells in the Center North HPA exceeded NMWQCC standards for SO42-, TDS, and Cl-. In the South HPA, all wells exceeded the standards for SO42-, all but one well for TDS, five wells for Cl-, and one well for F-. Two wells in the South HPA had pH values above nine. No TPH was detected above the reporting limits in any of the wells in 2019 or 2020. The total anion count for one well (N-2016-081) in the North HPA doubled from 2016 to 2019. One well in the Center North (CN-2015-013) saw large fluctuations in TDS, specific conductance, total cation, and total anion count. This was likely due to changes in sampling depth from 2016 to 2019. Finally, the pH in one well in the South HPA (S-2016-019) rose to above the NMWQCC standard upper limit of nine in 2020. Water level data were also collected from wells drilled to the Rustler Formation, Dockum Formation, and Capitan Reef. One well in the North HPA showed changes in water level indicative of seasonal variations while another well also in the North HPA showed water level changes associated with nearby pumping. In the Center North HPA one well drilled to the Rustler Formation indicated nearby pumping while two others drilled to the same formation did not show changes associated with pumping activities. Wells known to be drilled to the Dockum formation in the Center North HPA show recharge to the aquifer based on upward trending water levels. A similar trend is seen in the South HPA. Seven of the eight wells in the South HPA completed in the Rustler Formation showed water level responses due to nearby pumping, although it is difficult to determine for certain without continuous monitoring data. The water level in two wells completed to the Capitan Reef Aquifer indicated nearby pumping while two wells also completed in the Capitan Reef Aquifer showed water level increases and possible recharge to the aquifer. It is recommended that field testing be continued to monitor water quality and water level changes in the region. Monitoring for TPH should also continue, particularly in the South HPA where there is an increase in drilling activity. Finally, additional wells can be identified for continuous water level monitoring to augment the existing network, especially where manual water level measurements demonstrate significant increases or decreases in water levels and quarterly data points are not sufficient to determine the cause. 57 5.
